Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Expectation2: Provide emotional support and companionship to patients
Situation2: A patient is recovering from a recent surgery and appears anxious and a bit scared.
Story: Tonight is the only evening my girlfriend and I have together before I leave for a week-long training. She’s been looking forward to it, dropping hints about the new restaurant she wants to try and how much she’ll miss me. I promised her this night would be just for us. But as I’m about to clock out, the charge nurse pulls me aside. One of my patients, Mr. Harris, is recovering from surgery and is visibly anxious, asking if I could stay a little longer. He’s alone, his family lives out of state, and he keeps glancing at the door, hoping someone will come in. I know how much it means for patients to have someone there, especially at night when the ward gets quiet and fears grow louder. My phone buzzes with a text from my girlfriend: “Can’t wait to see you!” I feel the weight of both worlds pressing down on me—her hopeful anticipation, his silent plea. My heart aches, torn between being the boyfriend she needs and the caregiver he depends on. I stand in the hallway, keys in hand, caught in the pull of two promises I can’t keep at once.
